title.rendered: 1) What is Python? What are the benefits of using Python?

content.rendered: Python is a programming language with objects, modules, threads, exceptions and automatic memory management. The benefits of pythons are that it is simple and easy, portable, extensible, build-in data structure and it is an open source.

excerpt.rendered: Python is a programming language with objects, modules, threads, exceptions and automatic memory management. The benefits of pythons are that it is simple and easy, portable, extensible, build-in data structure and it is an open source.

title.rendered: 2) What is PEP 8?

content.rendered: PEP 8 is a coding convention, a set of recommendation, about how to write your Python code more readable.

excerpt.rendered: PEP 8 is a coding convention, a set of recommendation, about how to write your Python code more readable.

title.rendered: 3) What is pickling and unpickling?

content.rendered: Pickle module accepts any Python object and converts it into a string representation and dumps it into a file by using dump function, this process is called pickling. While the process of retrieving original Python objects from the stored string representation is called unpickling.

excerpt.rendered: Pickle module accepts any Python object and converts it into a string representation and dumps it into a file by using dump function, this process is called pickling. While the process of retrieving original Python objects from the stored string representation is called unpickling.

title.rendered: 4) How Python is interpreted?

content.rendered: Python language is an interpreted language. Python program runs directly from the source code. It converts the source code that is written by the programmer into an intermediate language, which is again translated into machine language that has to be executed.

excerpt.rendered: Python language is an interpreted language. Python program runs directly from the source code. It converts the source code that is written by the programmer into an intermediate language, which is again translated into machine language that has to be executed.

title.rendered: 5) How memory is managed in Python?

content.rendered:
• Python memory is managed by Python private heap space. All Python objects and data structures are located in a private heap. The programmer does not have an access to this private heap and interpreter takes care of this Python private heap.
  • The allocation of Python heap space for Python objects is done by Python memory manager. The core API gives access to some tools for the programmer to code.
  • Python also have an inbuilt garbage collector, which recycle all the unused memory and frees the memory and makes it available to the heap space.

excerpt.rendered: Python memory is managed by Python private heap space. All Python objects and data structures are located in a private heap. The programmer does not have an access to this private heap and interpreter takes care of this Python private heap. The allocation of Python heap space for Python objects is done by Python memory […]

title.rendered: 6) What are the tools that help to find bugs or perform static analysis?

content.rendered: PyChecker is a static analysis tool that detects the bugs in Python source code and warns about the style and complexity of the bug. Pylint is another tool that verifies whether the module meets the coding standard.

excerpt.rendered: PyChecker is a static analysis tool that detects the bugs in Python source code and warns about the style and complexity of the bug. Pylint is another tool that verifies whether the module meets the coding standard.

title.rendered: 7) What are Python decorators?

content.rendered: A Python decorator is a specific change that we make in Python syntax to alter functions easily.

excerpt.rendered: A Python decorator is a specific change that we make in Python syntax to alter functions easily.

title.rendered: 8) What is the difference between list and tuple?

content.rendered: The difference between list and tuple is that list is mutable while tuple is not. Tuple can be hashed for e.g as a key for dictionaries.

excerpt.rendered: The difference between list and tuple is that list is mutable while tuple is not. Tuple can be hashed for e.g as a key for dictionaries.

title.rendered: 9) How are arguments passed by value or by reference?

content.rendered: Everything in Python is an object and all variables hold references to the objects. The references values are according to the functions; as a result you cannot change the value of the references. However, you can change the objects if it is mutable.

excerpt.rendered: Everything in Python is an object and all variables hold references to the objects. The references values are according to the functions; as a result you cannot change the value of the references. However, you can change the objects if it is mutable.

title.rendered: 10) What is Dict and List comprehensions are?

content.rendered: They are syntax constructions to ease the creation of a Dictionary or List based on existing iterable.

excerpt.rendered: They are syntax constructions to ease the creation of a Dictionary or List based on existing iterable.

title.rendered: 11) What are the built-in type does python provides?

content.rendered:
There are mutable and Immutable types of Pythons built in types Mutable built-in types

  • List
  • Sets
  • Dictionaries

Immutable built-in types

  • Strings
  • Tuples
  • Numbers

excerpt.rendered: There are mutable and Immutable types of Pythons built in types Mutable built-in types List Sets Dictionaries Immutable built-in types Strings Tuples Numbers

title.rendered: 12) What is namespace in Python?

content.rendered: In Python, every name introduced has a place where it lives and can be hooked for. This is known as namespace. It is like a box where a variable name is mapped to the object placed. Whenever the variable is searched out, this box will be searched, to get corresponding object.

excerpt.rendered: In Python, every name introduced has a place where it lives and can be hooked for. This is known as namespace. It is like a box where a variable name is mapped to the object placed. Whenever the variable is searched out, this box will be searched, to get corresponding object.

title.rendered: 13) What is lambda in Python?

content.rendered: It is a single expression anonymous function often used as inline function.

excerpt.rendered: It is a single expression anonymous function often used as inline function.

title.rendered: 14) Why lambda forms in python does not have statements?

content.rendered: A lambda form in python does not have statements as it is used to make new function object and then return them at runtime.

excerpt.rendered: A lambda form in python does not have statements as it is used to make new function object and then return them at runtime.

title.rendered: 15) What is pass in Python?

content.rendered: Pass means, no-operation Python statement, or in other words it is a place holder in compound statement, where there should be a blank left and nothing has to be written there.

excerpt.rendered: Pass means, no-operation Python statement, or in other words it is a place holder in compound statement, where there should be a blank left and nothing has to be written there.

title.rendered: 16) In Python what are iterators?

content.rendered: In Python, iterators are used to iterate a group of elements, containers like list.

excerpt.rendered: In Python, iterators are used to iterate a group of elements, containers like list.

title.rendered: 17) What is unittest in Python?

content.rendered: A unit testing framework in Python is known as unittest. It supports sharing of setups, automation testing, shutdown code for tests, aggregation of tests into collections etc.

excerpt.rendered: A unit testing framework in Python is known as unittest. It supports sharing of setups, automation testing, shutdown code for tests, aggregation of tests into collections etc.

title.rendered: 18) In Python what is slicing?

content.rendered: A mechanism to select a range of items from sequence types like list, tuple, strings etc. is known as slicing.

excerpt.rendered: A mechanism to select a range of items from sequence types like list, tuple, strings etc. is known as slicing.

title.rendered: 19) What are generators in Python?

content.rendered: The way of implementing iterators are known as generators. It is a normal function except that it yields expression in the function.

excerpt.rendered: The way of implementing iterators are known as generators. It is a normal function except that it yields expression in the function.

title.rendered: 20) What is docstring in Python?

content.rendered: A Python documentation string is known as docstring, it is a way of documenting Python functions, modules and classes.

excerpt.rendered: A Python documentation string is known as docstring, it is a way of documenting Python functions, modules and classes.

title.rendered: 21) How can you copy an object in Python?

content.rendered: To copy an object in Python, you can try copy.copy () or copy.deepcopy() for the general case. You cannot copy all objects but most of them.

excerpt.rendered: To copy an object in Python, you can try copy.copy () or copy.deepcopy() for the general case. You cannot copy all objects but most of them.

title.rendered: 22) What is negative index in Python?

content.rendered: Python sequences can be index in positive and negative numbers. For positive index, 0 is the first index, 1 is the second index and so forth. For negative index, (-1) is the last index and (-2) is the second last index and so forth.

excerpt.rendered: Python sequences can be index in positive and negative numbers. For positive index, 0 is the first index, 1 is the second index and so forth. For negative index, (-1) is the last index and (-2) is the second last index and so forth.

title.rendered: 23) How you can convert a number to a string?

content.rendered: In order to convert a number into a string, use the inbuilt function str(). If you want a octal or hexadecimal representation, use the inbuilt function oct() or hex().

excerpt.rendered: In order to convert a number into a string, use the inbuilt function str(). If you want a octal or hexadecimal representation, use the inbuilt function oct() or hex().

title.rendered: 24) What is the difference between Xrange and range?

content.rendered: Xrange returns the xrange object while range returns the list, and uses the same memory and no matter what the range size is.

excerpt.rendered: Xrange returns the xrange object while range returns the list, and uses the same memory and no matter what the range size is.

title.rendered: 25) What is module and package in Python?

content.rendered:
In Python, module is the way to structure program. Each Python program file is a module, which imports other modules like objects and attributes.

The folder of Python program is a package of modules. A package can have modules or subfolders.

excerpt.rendered: In Python, module is the way to structure program. Each Python program file is a module, which imports other modules like objects and attributes. The folder of Python program is a package of modules. A package can have modules or subfolders.

title.rendered: 26) Mention what are the rules for local and global variables in Python?

content.rendered:
Local variables: If a variable is assigned a new value anywhere within the function’s body, it’s assumed to be local.

Global variables: Those variables that are only referenced inside a function are implicitly global.

excerpt.rendered: Local variables: If a variable is assigned a new value anywhere within the function’s body, it’s assumed to be local. Global variables: Those variables that are only referenced inside a function are implicitly global.

title.rendered: 27) How can you share global variables across modules?

content.rendered: To share global variables across modules within a single program, create a special module. Import the config module in all modules of your application. The module will be available as a global variable across modules.

excerpt.rendered: To share global variables across modules within a single program, create a special module. Import the config module in all modules of your application. The module will be available as a global variable across modules.

title.rendered: 28) Explain how can you make a Python Script executable on Unix?

content.rendered:
To make a Python Script executable on Unix, you need to do two things,

  • Script file’s mode must be executable and
  • the first line must begin with # ( #!/usr/local/bin/python)

excerpt.rendered: To make a Python Script executable on Unix, you need to do two things, Script file’s mode must be executable and the first line must begin with # ( #!/usr/local/bin/python)

title.rendered: 29) Explain how to delete a file in Python?

content.rendered: By using a command os.remove (filename) or os.unlink(filename)

excerpt.rendered: By using a command os.remove (filename) or os.unlink(filename)

title.rendered: 30) Explain how can you generate random numbers in Python?

content.rendered:
To generate random numbers in Python, you need to import command as

import random

random.random()

This returns a random floating point number in the range [0,1)

excerpt.rendered: To generate random numbers in Python, you need to import command as import random random.random() This returns a random floating point number in the range [0,1)

title.rendered: 31) Explain how can you access a module written in Python from C?

content.rendered:
You can access a module written in Python from C by following method,

Module = =PyImport_ImportModule(“<modulename>”);

excerpt.rendered: You can access a module written in Python from C by following method, Module = =PyImport_ImportModule(“<modulename>”);

title.rendered: 32) Mention the use of // operator in Python?

content.rendered: It is a Floor Divisionoperator , which is used for dividing two operands with the result as quotient showing only digits before the decimal point. For instance, 10//5 = 2 and 10.0//5.0 = 2.0.

excerpt.rendered: It is a Floor Divisionoperator , which is used for dividing two operands with the result as quotient showing only digits before the decimal point. For instance, 10//5 = 2 and 10.0//5.0 = 2.0.

content.rendered:
• Python comprises of a huge standard library for most Internet platforms like Email, HTML, etc.
  • Python does not require explicit memory management as the interpreter itself allocates the memory to new variables and free them automatically

  • Easy-to-learn for beginners
  • Having the built-in data types saves programming time and effort from declaring variables

title.rendered: 34) Mention the use of the split function in Python?

content.rendered: The use of the split function in Python is that it breaks a string into shorter strings using the defined separator. It gives a list of all words present in the string.

excerpt.rendered: The use of the split function in Python is that it breaks a string into shorter strings using the defined separator. It gives a list of all words present in the string.

title.rendered: 35) Explain what is Flask & its benefits?

content.rendered:
Flask is a web micro framework for Python based on “Werkzeug, Jinja 2 and good intentions” BSD licensed. Werkzeug and jingja are two of its dependencies.

Flask is part of the micro-framework. Which means it will have little to no dependencies on external libraries. It makes the framework light while there is little dependency to update and less security bugs.

excerpt.rendered: Flask is a web micro framework for Python based on “Werkzeug, Jinja 2 and good intentions” BSD licensed. Werkzeug and jingja are two of its dependencies. Flask is part of the micro-framework. Which means it will have little to no dependencies on external libraries. It makes the framework light while there is little dependency to […]

title.rendered: 36) Mention what is the difference between Django, Pyramid, and Flask?

content.rendered:
Flask is a “microframework” primarily build for a small application with simpler requirements. In flask, you don’t have to use external libraries. Flask is ready to use.

Pyramid are build for larger applications. It provides flexibility and lets the developer use the right tools for their project. The developer can choose the database, URL structure, templating style and more. Pyramid is heavy configurable.

Like Pyramid, Django can also used for larger applications. It includes an ORM.

excerpt.rendered: Flask is a “microframework” primarily build for a small application with simpler requirements. In flask, you don’t have to use external libraries. Flask is ready to use. Pyramid are build for larger applications. It provides flexibility and lets the developer use the right tools for their project. The developer can choose the database, URL structure, […]

title.rendered: 37) Mention what is Flask-WTF and what are their features?

content.rendered:
Flask-WTF offers simple integration with WTForms. Features include for Flask WTF are

  • Integration with wtforms
  • Secure form with csrf token
  • Global csrf protection
  • Internationalization integration
  • Recaptcha supporting
  • File upload that works with Flask Uploads

excerpt.rendered: Flask-WTF offers simple integration with WTForms. Features include for Flask WTF are Integration with wtforms Secure form with csrf token Global csrf protection Internationalization integration Recaptcha supporting File upload that works with Flask Uploads

title.rendered: 38) Explain what is the common way for the Flask script to work?

content.rendered:
The common way for the flask script to work is

  • Either it should be the import path for your application
  • Or the path to a Python file

excerpt.rendered: The common way for the flask script to work is Either it should be the import path for your application Or the path to a Python file

title.rendered: 39) What is “Call by Reference” in Python?

content.rendered:
We use both “call-by-reference” and “pass-by-reference” interchangeably. When we pass an argument by reference, then it is available as an implicit reference to the function, rather than a simple copy. In such a case, any modification to the argument will also be visible to the caller.

This scheme also has the advantage of bringing more time and space efficiency because it leaves the need for creating local copies.

On the contrary, the disadvantage could be that a variable can get changed accidentally during a function call. Hence, the programmers need to handle in the code to avoid such uncertainty.

excerpt.rendered: We use both “call-by-reference” and “pass-by-reference” interchangeably. When we pass an argument by reference, then it is available as an implicit reference to the function, rather than a simple copy. In such a case, any modification to the argument will also be visible to the caller. This scheme also has the advantage of bringing more […]

title.rendered: 40) What is the return value of the trunc() function?

content.rendered: The Python trunc() function performs a mathematical operation to remove the decimal values from a particular expression and provides an integer value as its output.

excerpt.rendered: The Python trunc() function performs a mathematical operation to remove the decimal values from a particular expression and provides an integer value as its output.

title.rendered: 41) Is it mandatory for a Python function to return a value?

content.rendered: It is not at all necessary for a function to return any value. However, if needed, we can use None as a return value.

excerpt.rendered: It is not at all necessary for a function to return any value. However, if needed, we can use None as a return value.

title.rendered: 42) What does the continue do in Python?

content.rendered:
The continue is a jump statement in Python which moves the control to execute the next iteration in a loop leaving all the remaining instructions in the block unexecuted.

The continue statement is applicable for both the “while” and “for” loops.

excerpt.rendered: The continue is a jump statement in Python which moves the control to execute the next iteration in a loop leaving all the remaining instructions in the block unexecuted. The continue statement is applicable for both the “while” and “for” loops.

title.rendered: 43) What is the purpose of id() function in Python?

content.rendered:
The id() is one of the built-in functions in Python.

Signature: id(object)

It accepts one parameter and returns a unique identifier associated with the input object.

excerpt.rendered: The id() is one of the built-in functions in Python. Signature: id(object) It accepts one parameter and returns a unique identifier associated with the input object.

title.rendered: 44) What does the *args do in Python?

content.rendered:
We use *args as a parameter in the function header. It gives us the ability to pass N (variable) number of arguments.

Please note that this type of argument syntax doesn’t allow passing a named argument to the function.

Example of using the *args:

# Python code to demonstrate 
# *args for dynamic arguments 
def fn(*argList):  
    for argx in argList:  
        print (argx) 
    
fn('I', 'am', 'Learning', 'Python')

The output:

I
am
Learning
Python

excerpt.rendered: We use *args as a parameter in the function header. It gives us the ability to pass N (variable) number of arguments. Please note that this type of argument syntax doesn’t allow passing a named argument to the function. Example of using the *args: The output:

title.rendered: 45) What does the **kwargs do in Python?

content.rendered:
We can also use the **kwargs syntax in a Python function declaration. It let us pass N (variable) number of arguments which can be named or keyworded.

Example of using the **kwargs:

# Python code to demonstrate 
# **kwargs for dynamic + named arguments 
def fn(**kwargs):  
    for emp, age in kwargs.items(): 
        print ("%s's age is %s." %(emp, age)) 
    
fn(John=25, Kalley=22, Tom=32)

The output:

John's age is 25.
Kalley's age is 22.
Tom's age is 32.

excerpt.rendered: We can also use the **kwargs syntax in a Python function declaration. It let us pass N (variable) number of arguments which can be named or keyworded. Example of using the **kwargs: The output:

title.rendered: 46) Does Python have a Main() method?

content.rendered:
The main() is the entry point function which happens to be called first in most programming languages.

Since Python is interpreter-based, so it sequentially executes the lines of the code one-by-one.

Python also does have a Main() method. But it gets executed whenever we run our Python script either by directly clicking it or starts it from the command line.

We can also override the Python default main() function using the Python if statement. Please see the below code.

print("Welcome")
print("__name__ contains: ", __name__)
def main():
    print("Testing the main function")
if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

The output:

Welcome
__name__ contains:  __main__
Testing the main function

excerpt.rendered: The main() is the entry point function which happens to be called first in most programming languages. Since Python is interpreter-based, so it sequentially executes the lines of the code one-by-one. Python also does have a Main() method. But it gets executed whenever we run our Python script either by directly clicking it or starts […]

title.rendered: 47) What does the __ Name __ do in Python?

content.rendered:
The __name__ is a unique variable. Since Python doesn’t expose the main() function, so when its interpreter gets to run the script, it first executes the code which is at level 0 indentation.

To see whether the main() gets called, we can use the __name__ variable in an if clause compares with the value “__main__.”

excerpt.rendered: The __name__ is a unique variable. Since Python doesn’t expose the main() function, so when its interpreter gets to run the script, it first executes the code which is at level 0 indentation. To see whether the main() gets called, we can use the __name__ variable in an if clause compares with the value “__main__.”

title.rendered: 48) What is the purpose of “end” in Python?

content.rendered:
Python’s print() function always prints a newline in the end. The print() function accepts an optional parameter known as the ‘end.’ Its value is ‘\n’ by default. We can change the end character in a print statement with the value of our choice using this parameter.

# Example: Print a  instead of the new line in the end.
print("Let's learn" , end = ' ')  
print("Python") 

# Printing a dot in the end.
print("Learn to code from Codemeals.com" , end = '.')  
print("com", end = ' ')

The output is:

Let's learn Python
Learn to code from Codemeals.com

excerpt.rendered: Python’s print() function always prints a newline in the end. The print() function accepts an optional parameter known as the ‘end.’ Its value is ‘\n’ by default. We can change the end character in a print statement with the value of our choice using this parameter. The output is:

title.rendered: 49) When should you use the “break” in Python?

content.rendered:
Python provides a break statement to exit from a loop. Whenever the break hits in the code, the control of the program immediately exits from the body of the loop.

The break statement in a nested loop causes the control to exit from the inner iterative block.

excerpt.rendered: Python provides a break statement to exit from a loop. Whenever the break hits in the code, the control of the program immediately exits from the body of the loop. The break statement in a nested loop causes the control to exit from the inner iterative block.

title.rendered: 50) What is the difference between pass and continue in Python?

content.rendered:
The continue statement makes the loop to resume from the next iteration.

On the contrary, the pass statement instructs to do nothing, and the remainder of the code executes as usual.

excerpt.rendered: The continue statement makes the loop to resume from the next iteration. On the contrary, the pass statement instructs to do nothing, and the remainder of the code executes as usual.

title.rendered: 51) What does the len() function do in Python?

content.rendered:
In Python, the len() is a primary string function. It determines the length of an input string.

>>> some_string = 'Codemeals'
>>> len(some_string)
11

excerpt.rendered: In Python, the len() is a primary string function. It determines the length of an input string.

title.rendered: 52) What does the chr() function do in Python?

content.rendered:
The chr() function got re-added in Python 3.2. In version 3.0, it got removed.

It returns the string denoting a character whose Unicode code point is an integer.

For example, the chr(122) returns the string ‘z’ whereas the chr(1212) returns the string ‘Ҽ’.

excerpt.rendered: The chr() function got re-added in Python 3.2. In version 3.0, it got removed. It returns the string denoting a character whose Unicode code point is an integer. For example, the chr(122) returns the string ‘z’ whereas the chr(1212) returns the string ‘Ҽ’.

title.rendered: 53) What does the ord() function do in Python?

content.rendered:
The ord(char) in Python takes a string of size one and returns an integer denoting the Unicode code format of the character in case of a Unicode type object, or the value of the byte if the argument is of 8-bit string type.

>>> ord("z")
122

excerpt.rendered: The ord(char) in Python takes a string of size one and returns an integer denoting the Unicode code format of the character in case of a Unicode type object, or the value of the byte if the argument is of 8-bit string type. >>> ord(“z”) 122

title.rendered: 54) What is Rstrip() in Python?

content.rendered:
Python provides the rstrip() method which duplicates the string but leaves out the whitespace characters from the end.

The rstrip() escapes the characters from the right end based on the argument value, i.e., a string mentioning the group of characters to get excluded.

The signature of the rstrip() is:

str.rstrip([char sequence/pre>
#Example
test_str = 'Programming    '
# The trailing whitespaces are excluded
print(test_str.rstrip())

excerpt.rendered: Python provides the rstrip() method which duplicates the string but leaves out the whitespace characters from the end. The rstrip() escapes the characters from the right end based on the argument value, i.e., a string mentioning the group of characters to get excluded. The signature of the rstrip() is: str.rstrip([char sequence/pre>

title.rendered: 55) What is whitespace in Python?

content.rendered:
Whitespace represents the characters that we use for spacing and separation.

They possess an “empty” representation. In Python, it could be a tab or space.

excerpt.rendered: Whitespace represents the characters that we use for spacing and separation. They possess an “empty” representation. In Python, it could be a tab or space.

title.rendered: 56) What is isalpha() in Python?

content.rendered:
Python provides this built-in isalpha() function for the string handling purpose.

It returns True if all characters in the string are of alphabet type, else it returns False.

excerpt.rendered: Python provides this built-in isalpha() function for the string handling purpose. It returns True if all characters in the string are of alphabet type, else it returns False.

title.rendered: 57) How do you use the split() function in Python?

content.rendered:
Python’s split() function works on strings to cut a large piece into smaller chunks, or sub-strings. We can specify a separator to start splitting, or it uses the space as one by default.

#Example
str = 'pdf csv json'
print(str.split(" "))
print(str.split())

The output:

['pdf', 'csv', 'json']
['pdf', 'csv', 'json']

excerpt.rendered: Python’s split() function works on strings to cut a large piece into smaller chunks, or sub-strings. We can specify a separator to start splitting, or it uses the space as one by default. The output:

title.rendered: 58) What does the join method do in Python?

content.rendered: Python provides the join() method which works on strings, lists, and tuples. It combines them and returns a united value.

excerpt.rendered: Python provides the join() method which works on strings, lists, and tuples. It combines them and returns a united value.

title.rendered: 59) What does the Title() method do in Python?

content.rendered:
Python provides the title() method to convert the first letter in each word to capital format while the rest turns to Lowercase.

#Example
str = 'lEaRn pYtHoN'
print(str.title())

The output:

Learn Python

Now, check out some general purpose Python interview questions.

excerpt.rendered: Python provides the title() method to convert the first letter in each word to capital format while the rest turns to Lowercase. The output: Now, check out some general purpose Python interview questions.

title.rendered: 60)What makes the CPython different from Python?

content.rendered: CPython has its core developed in C. The prefix ‘C’ represents this fact. It runs an interpreter loop used for translating the Python-ish code to C language.

excerpt.rendered: CPython has its core developed in C. The prefix ‘C’ represents this fact. It runs an interpreter loop used for translating the Python-ish code to C language.

title.rendered: 61)Which package is the fastest form of Python?

content.rendered:
PyPy provides maximum compatibility while utilizing CPython implementation for improving its performance.

The tests confirmed that PyPy is nearly five times faster than the CPython. It currently supports Python 2.7.

excerpt.rendered: PyPy provides maximum compatibility while utilizing CPython implementation for improving its performance. The tests confirmed that PyPy is nearly five times faster than the CPython. It currently supports Python 2.7.

title.rendered: 62)What is GIL in Python language?

content.rendered: Python supports GIL (the global interpreter lock) which is a mutex used to secure access to Python objects, synchronizing multiple threads from running the Python bytecodes at the same time.

excerpt.rendered: Python supports GIL (the global interpreter lock) which is a mutex used to secure access to Python objects, synchronizing multiple threads from running the Python bytecodes at the same time.

title.rendered: 63) How is Python thread safe?

content.rendered:
Python ensures safe access to threads. It uses the GIL mutex to set synchronization. If a thread loses the GIL lock at any time, then you have to make the code thread-safe.

For example, many of the Python operations execute as atomic such as calling the sort() method on a list.

excerpt.rendered: Python ensures safe access to threads. It uses the GIL mutex to set synchronization. If a thread loses the GIL lock at any time, then you have to make the code thread-safe. For example, many of the Python operations execute as atomic such as calling the sort() method on a list.
